Posts.Content: I did see a radiologist oncologists, who said because of the history, staging and psa 5.6, extent and location of tumors, double(ebrt+ seeds) or triple approach(ebrt+seeds+short term hormone therapy) is my best option. Surgery would not, again primarily due to extent of apex and base involvement with perineural invasion I did also have a second read on the pathology report, it was similar except the core percentages changed slightly and the 7's in the second report went from 4=3 to 3=4 and added preineural invasion present. I would highly recommend getting a second report because your treatment flows from that, in my case it was similar enough not to change my outcome The urology oncologist is a surgeon who specializes in bladder reconstruction, so that's a plus for the urinary sphincter proximity to the apex tumor, he said he has done thousands of open prostatectomies and 400 robotic, and he now does only robotic Highlander, how did the surgeon know of the extent of positive margin prior to surgery?
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Who to see to decide what's the best treatment to follow? Clear as mud

Posts.Content: One more question(for now) the uro oncologists gave me a prescription for a Pelvic MRI with contrast, as an aid in his approach to surgery. If I go with radiation instead, is that a necessary test? Will it provide me with information that will be useful to me? Not sure how detailed or how low a level of cancer it can detect? I would like to avoid the risk of injected contrast dye and the co-pay. so If I don't need it...
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Who to see to decide what's the best treatment to follow? Clear as mud

Posts.Content: Just back from the consult with the urology oncologist. This facility offers RRP and EBRT & seeds. He basically said surgery is my best option, however, I had 8 cores positive both sides, plus the largest involvement in the apex and base, not good for being completely contained, T2C staging(for now) which is why I am told by others, that radiation would be the best approach...So, the RO and the surgeon are completely at both ends of the spectrum.. Is there an unbiased physician or service that one can go to for help in deciding which treatment is best, based on personal stats? The detail about the surgery was sobering, especially with the apex involvement, urinary sphincter, cutting the urethra, possible nerve and lymph node removal....
Posts.Title: Who to see to decide what's the best treatment to follow? Clear as mud

Posts.Content: You're right, T2C may be upgraded, depending on 30% chance of extra capsular extension. My urologist first gave me the wrong staging, the number of cores with G7 moves me into the intermediate risk. He also told me my prostate was small. The report I have reads 64.82cc, which is double normal size? time for a new uro? After blood test for creatinine level,I have a script for a MRI Pelvis with contrast, the fun never ends, welcome aboard. This is why I postponed the biopsy, I didn't want to open this door....

AgeInfo.Phrase: The report I have reads 64 82cc  which is double normal

Posts.Content: Thanks for the replies, I was just hoping not to have the biopsy done. The local urologist graduated from Johns Hopkins, board certified, PHD and has a good rep. Guess I will keep my scheduled appointment for next Friday. As for Wheeler, they do a 1/2 day work up with scans. Seems to have been doing this before the technology was there. That plus all the other ancillary services they provide is a little suspicious. They don't accept insurance, so it would be $5,000 out of pocket and I may need a biopsy anyway. Any recommendations for getting prepared for the staple gun in the ass procedure? They do provide 10mg valium and one percocet

Posts.Title: Suspect Alternative to Biopsy from first time confused poster

Posts.Content: I am 56 years old, in 07 psa 2.9/ 2011 psa 5/ two weeks of cipro psa 4.3. with free psa of 26%. Recently checked again psa 5.6, DRE abnormal in 2011, now same urologists says it feels normal in 2012?? Symptoms, low flow and frequent night urination. No immediate family deaths related to PC I am scheduled for my first biopsy TRUL, but I came across a Dr Robert Wheeler in Sarasota who is promoting an MRI in place of a biopsy. How could he have this technology for years now and no one knows about it? It is difficult to determine if there is any validity to his various claims. Does anyone have any knowledge about this? As I am hesitant to go for the biopsy due to the risk of infection, needle tracking of cancer cells, and false negatives, pain and humiliation etc... any advice is appreciated

AgeInfo.Phrase: <Z> <Z> <Z> I am 56 years old  in 07 psa

Posts.Content: Read the book "invasion of the prostate snatchers" for starters. Those numbers are within normal limits for someone your age, even low. The recent increase can be from many different reasons other then Pca. Ask your urologist about a pcs3 test
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Additional Tests?

Posts.Content: I haven't started yet, but my neighbor just completed a similar program. Just spoke with him today about his experience. He said, no problems with the first 5 weeks at all. After the seed implants he said he would have gone back to work the next day, except for other unrelated health issues. I was surprised at that. I think if all goes well, expect urgency to urinate, nocturnia and some burning while urinating, which gradually decreases. Also depends on many factors, your health, the staging and the experience of the RO is probably the most important. His and mine has done over 4000 seed implants, has this figured out. The other posters so far had this as "salvage therapy" which adds complications
Posts.Title: Do You Keep Working ?

Posts.Content: This is what I ended up with, told the gold markers are older technology http://www.dattoli.com/prostate-canc...celerator/i/37
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: External Radiation options

Posts.Content: Down to two options, local RO or Dattoli clinic Local RO had my prostate measured by their own in-house tech, standard b&w ultra sound at 39cc, doctor not present, but tech with 20+ years experience. At my 2nd opinion consult with Dr Dattoli, with him participating, color doppler ultra sound, prostate measured at 65.1cc? I was able to see with my own monitor while they mapped and measured the gland and to see the tumors. Some on the margins with extra capsular extensions present, as I expected from my path report. Really sobering to see the offending tumors in real time Hard to believe the readings are so far apart. Local RO uses gold markers for external IMRT, which once set don't change, even if prostate moves during treatment. The DART technology(Dattoli) supposedly accounts for movement(breathing, organ shifting, internal gas, bladder filling, etc. and self corrects in real time, resulting in more accurate dosing which means less collateral damage. The obvious choice, based on the above is to go with the Dattoli clinic. If local RO has this wrong? Haven't even started yet, yikes. BTW, the original biopsy the prostate measured 64cc Comments appreciated as my treatment has started, Casdex/Avodart and need to choose between RO's in the next day or two.

AgeInfo.Phrase: standard b&w ultra sound at 39cc  doctor not present  but tech

Posts.Title: Prostate size way off, DART versus gold Markers

Posts.Content: Is this what you are referring to? • After your initial consultation visit, you will return to the center for a “Simulation” or “SIM”. This is a 3-D anatomical simulation of your pelvis (and/or other indicated areas) will be completed with a Computed Tomography Scan (CAT Scan). Contrast is instilled in the bladder through a urinary catheter that has been placed during this scan, as well as separate rectal catheter. • A special, customized (molded) alpha cradle will be made for you for use as lower body immobilization during your daily treatments. (Remember: that whatever pair of shoes you wear when the cradle is made, you will need to wear for each of your treatments.) • A note on SHOES: Patients who undergo 4D IG-IMRT simulation and daily treatment must wear a shoe having substantial contour. This may include, but is not limited to, a hard leather dress shoe and/or a running shoe (not a walking shoe). A hiking boot/shoe would also suffice. Refer to pictures provided at consult for acceptable shoes.
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement

Posts.Content: Thanks Guys, I'm going with The Dattoli center, 2 1/2 hour round trip drive, more out of pocket $$$ but hey, if I am going to be seeded and micro waved, I want the best doctor and technology I can get. They know what they are doing, very detailed and seem to have all angles of this thing covered with the latest technology. I feel comfortable with this decision and I'm glad I kept this final consult, almost cancelled it, but figured it can't hurt to collect as much information as possible prior to jumping into treatment. Now if the pain from this damn shingles outbreak would subside I can relax a little bit. almost be a relief to finally start treatment.

Posts.Title: Prostate size way off, DART versus gold Markers

Posts.Content: Ditto what John T said. If I had your report instead of mine, I would never rush into any treatment that may affect quality of life permanently. I'd go active surveillance and only consider treatment if things progressed.. How others rush out for treatment with similar stats is beyond me. If you take the time to educate yourself, you can make a decision you are comfortable with. You have time, so relax and start your research

Posts.Title: Introduction

Posts.Content: I am new to this but have spent an inordinate amount of time researching my own situation. You don't mention what your Gleason score was. If 6 or less, in the limited amount found, active surveillance would still seem appropriate, unless you had a much higher psa. You're saying the psa went up to 3.5 in 2008 and is still about the same? Typically that type of biopsy is done when there is a significant rise in the psa but the biopsies are coming back negative. Anyway I don't have an answer for you but I am interested in what others have to say about it. At least I avoided that type of biopsy with my loaded results
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement

Posts.Title: Perineal Biopsy

Posts.Content: Look into a TRUS guided biopsy using color doppler ultra sound. I have no personal experience with them but I remember reading somewhere they can view tumors with more precision then standard ultra sound, thus allowing a more targeted biopsy. I would look into that as a possible option to the one you are thinking of, hopefully others with more knowledge about them will comment

Posts.Content: Just started generic flomax for the beginning of the treatment journey, stuffy sinus unable to sleep, loss of libido, weak ejaculate, just a pathetic way to start, not feeling good from it. I started flomax thinking I'm getting ebrt/seeds and maybe 6 month of hormones per RO instructions. Scared to think how the actual treatment going to be if I can't make it past this..seems trite considering what others are going through, although I'm about to enter the unknown and my report isn't that great to start Any reasonable alternatives to Tamusolin?
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Alternatives to tamulosin?

Posts.Content: Expected a flood of positive reviews? No one has any information about them? My other RO choice wasn't requesting what they are; Obtain comprehensive bloodwork to include a PSA, percent free PSA, PAP (prostatic acid phosphatase), bone specific alkaline phosphatase (BSAP), IGF-1, testosterone panel (includes a total and bio- available testosterone, sex hormone binding globulin, DHEAS, DHT, androstenedione, prolactin LH, estradiol), LDH, vitamin D,1,25, D,25-hydroxy, vit B12, folate, N-telopeptide, crosslinked, PTH (parathyroid hormone), calcitonin, osteocalcin, and urinalysis with cytology. -Obtain a whole body bone scan to evaluate total body skeleton for any abnormality or associated medical boney conditions. I have mailed you the prescription to have this performed closer to you. An 18F PET/CT would only be indicated if there is an abnormality identified on the bone scan, so not necessary to get this now. Second patholgy report reading -The first foraml consultation with Dr. Dattoli will include: a. A 3D color flow Doppler ultrasound with penile vascular imaging, b. A bone mineral densitometry scan (QCT scan) to evaluate bone density and risk of osteoporosis. c. Fine section (2mm) helical CT scans of the chest/abdomen/pelvis for the purpose of determining any anatomical treatment related considerations. -Obtain copies of all relevant medical records prior to your consultation appointment (i.e. biopsy report, lab results, x-ray/scan reports, physician office notes, ultrasound reports, procedure notes, most recent colonoscopy report).
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Dattoli Center Recommendations and insurance question

Posts.Content: I am approximately 70 miles north of The Dattoli Cancer Center, where they specialize in non-surgical treatment of prostate cancer . They are out of network, but my maximum per person for out of network is $5,000 per year. I take that to mean anything over $5,000 would be covered. If I go in network, my max out of pocket is $2,500 per person per year Does anyone have any experience with them, and if it makes sense to have treatment that far from where you live and pay the additional costs? Have to look a this as having one good shot at beating this thing. I need a break from the internet and thinking about prostate anything

AgeInfo.Phrase: insurance question I am approximately 70 miles north of The Dattoli

Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Dattoli Center Recommendations and insurance question

Posts.Content: 56 years old. PSA 2.9 - 5.6 from 2007 to 2012. DRE normal. Well my 12 core biopsy Shows 7 cores positive as follows Left Mid G-6 4% 0.5mm Left Apex G-6 25% 4mm Left Lat Mid G-6 15% 2mm Right Base G-7 30% 3mm Right Apex G-7 40% 4mm Right Lat Base G-7 11% 2mm Right Lat Apex G-6 3% 0.3mm I really expected a negative biopsy, I wasn't prepared for this. I just got back from the follow up, a little stunned at the moment From what I understand AS is not an option, while the Gleason scores are not showing as that aggressive, the fact 7 of 12 on both sides is not good. So my questions, a second pathology report would maybe shift some scoring one way or another, but not really change my prognosis. So I don't think it matters. I am leaning towards robotic with a very experienced surgeon. The other treatments if unsuccessful can ruin your surgical options if they don't work, and they are not risk free anyway Surgeons in West Central Florida? Any advice appreciated

AgeInfo.Phrase: Diagnosed  Need Help With findings 56 years old <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Diagnosed/ Need Help With findings

Posts.Content: 2nd pathology report findings, any comments appreciated as I am meeting with a radiology oncologist next week 2ND OPINION RECEIVED 11/15/2012 MICROSCOPIC DESCRIPTION A) Left Base: Benign prostatic glands and stroma. B) Left Mid: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 2mm (10% of the tissue). C) Left Apex: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 7mm (40% of the tissue). D) Left Base Lat: Benign prostatic glands and stroma. E) Left Lat Mid: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 2.5mm (20% of the tissue). F) Left Lat Apex: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 1mm (7% of the tissue). G) Right Base: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7, measuring 4mm (30% of the tissue). H) Right Mid: Small focus of atypical glands. I) Right Apex: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7, measuring 5mm (40% of the tissue). J) Right Lat Base: Prostatic adencarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 3mm (30% of the tissue). K) Right Lat Mid: Small focus of atypical glands. L) Right Lat Apex: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 1mm (5% of the tissue). Comments: Perineural invasion is seen in these biopsies. Eight of twelve tissue cores are involved with adenocarcinoma. PHOTOMICROGRAPH Malignant Report Date: 11/16/2012 All malignant
Posts.Title: Diagnosed/ Need Help With findings

Posts.Content: Had a 2nd pathology report showing "perineural invasion"(nice terminology) I guess that means I am less of a candidate for surgery now then even before, this is really sinking in, feeling scared of how serious this really is, I fully expected the biopsy report to be negative..any positive comments will be appreciated, nor feeling too good a the moment

Posts.Content: Had a 2nd pathology report showing "perineural invasion"(nice terminology) I guess that means I am less of a candidate for surgery now then even before, this is really sinking in, feeling scared of how serious this really is, I fully expected the biopsy report to be negative..any positive comments will be appreciated, nor feeling too good a the moment
Posts.Title: Diagnosed/ Need Help With findings

Posts.Content: 2nd pathology report findings, any comments appreciated as I am meeting with a radiology oncologist next week 2ND OPINION RECEIVED 11/15/2012 MICROSCOPIC DESCRIPTION A) Left Base: Benign prostatic glands and stroma. B) Left Mid: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 2mm (10% of the tissue). C) Left Apex: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 7mm (40% of the tissue). D) Left Base Lat: Benign prostatic glands and stroma. E) Left Lat Mid: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 2.5mm (20% of the tissue). F) Left Lat Apex: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 1mm (7% of the tissue). G) Right Base: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7, measuring 4mm (30% of the tissue). H) Right Mid: Small focus of atypical glands. I) Right Apex: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7, measuring 5mm (40% of the tissue). J) Right Lat Base: Prostatic adencarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 3mm (30% of the tissue). K) Right Lat Mid: Small focus of atypical glands. L) Right Lat Apex: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 1mm (5% of the tissue). Comments: Perineural invasion is seen in these biopsies. Eight of twelve tissue cores are involved with adenocarcinoma. PHOTOMICROGRAPH Malignant Report Date: 11/16/2012 All malignant
Posts.Title: Diagnosed/ Need Help With findings

Posts.Content: From my first DRE, Urologist estimated prostate size at 40 grams, second DRE one year later, same doc now says 30 grams. He specifically stated to my wife and myself,"your prostate is small". This concerned me due to the BPH related symptoms I had been having, which started this whole excursion, and the problems with urinary retention 1 day after the biopsy, almost prompting a trip to the ER If my prostate is not enlarged why these problems? From ultra sound guided biopsy, it measured 64.82cc From most recent pelvic MRI with contrast states "The prostate gland is enlarged measuring 5.0cm x 4.2cm x 4.0cm indenting the base of the bladder" Can anyone translate this info as to large this is? The rest of the report was basically"unremarkable" which was a huge relief, even though it's not sensitive enough to pick up smaller cancers, at least I was spared the added shock and misery of larger tumors, Is there a prostate size that would eliminate one from being a candidate from radiation? I know they will chemically shrink the gland prior to starting, but if radiation is successful, I will still have to deal with enlarged prostate issues after the treatment. With my stats, if I elect surgery that issue will be eliminated but I most likely will need radiation anyway, so I'm doubling the risk from both treatments, as Terry Herbert says, the only rules of prostate cancer is there are no rules... Any advice on these ramblings?
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Prostate Size When Considering Radiation?

Posts.Content: Thanks for responding to my latest conundrum and John, are you still on hormone treatment, or has the combination of short term hormone and radiation permanently shrunk the infamous prostate(intelligent design indeed) One more thing, the current RO is planning 2 weeks of Casodex, with 6 months of Lupron, injected. I like your choice of drug therapy better for obvious reasons, I will see if my RO is open to that idea
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Prostate Size When Considering Radiation?

Posts.Content: There are many variables to consider. I am getting treatment with a combination of EBRT and seeds and short term hormone treatment. If there are existing urinary problems, they will need to be addressed prior to starting treatment. If it's only from an enlarged prostate, a combo of avodart or proscar, to shrink the prostate, may be given along with hormone therapy like Casodex. Without more details and what has already been tried, it's hard to provide better advice. Try the Dattoli Cancer Center in Sarasota Florida, they can help answering questions for you.
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy with enlarged prostate

Posts.Content: Met with the radiology oncologist today, one more DRE, how nice. Based on my situation he thinks my best chance at beating this is EBRT for 5 weeks, followed by permanent seed implants, with an option for additional hormone therapy,2 weeks prior on Casodex and then 6 months of Lupron injections. The hormone optional, depending if I want to "throw the kitchen sink" at it, but not essential. I have to decide if the potential side effects are worth the potential benefits of adding the hormone therapy Similar treatment plan to what some of you graciously recommended So what are your thoughts on adding the hormone therapy? I had asked him, if I were a good candidate for surgery would he tell me. His answer surprised me. He referred me to the grimm study on prostate cancer(poor choice of name for this doc), that is supposedly unbiased, showing this 2 or 3 prong radiation approach is superior to surgery for survival rates and less side effects. One of my fears is having surgery with finding positive margins, due to the degree of cancer throughout my prostate along with the perineural invasion, requiring salvage radiation, compounding the worst side effects of both. He has done over 4,000 seed implants, he states, the advances in technology have increased dramatically allowing for ever more precise targeting of the prostate, resulting in less damage to surrounding organs What do you think? 2ND OPINION on pathology report PSA 5.6 8 of 12 cores positive A) Left Base: Benign prostatic glands and stroma. B) Left Mid: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 2mm (10% of the tissue). C) Left Apex: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 7mm (40% of the tissue). D) Left Base Lat: Benign prostatic glands and stroma. E) Left Lat Mid: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 2.5mm (20% of the tissue). F) Left Lat Apex: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 1mm (7% of the tissue). G) Right Base: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7, measuring 4mm (30% of the tissue). H) Right Mid: Small focus of atypical glands. I) Right Apex: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7, measuring 5mm (40% of the tissue). J) Right Lat Base: Prostatic adencarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 3mm (30% of the tissue). K) Right Lat Mid: Small focus of atypical glands. L) Right Lat Apex: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+3=6, measuring 1mm (5% of the tissue). Comments: Perineural invasion is seen in these biopsies. Eight of twelve tissue cores are involved with adenocarcinoma. PHOTOMICROGRAPH Malignant Report
Posts.Title: Radiology oncologist consult

Posts.Content: The study includes unbiased results taking into account all forms(including surgery) of treatment for the three levels of PC, low, intermediate and high risk. My RO emailed me a copy, it's in a power point format 5mb. If anybody wants to see it, send me an email [emailprotected]. I am still keeping my appointment with the Urology oncologists on Dec 4th at Lakeland Regional Cancer Center, they specialize in: Surgical Oncology, Radiation Oncology, Medical Oncology, Urology/Urologic Oncology. They have all forms of treatment under one roof. I plan to go in with my pathology reports and history but without adding what I know about this recent option presented to me. Then I take time to analyze what it all means...thanks to this site and the participants it is becoming manageable.
Posts.Title: Radiology oncologist consult

Posts.Content: One thing about this approach, I already have nocturnia and low flow, and maybe don't empty the bladder completely(not sure about that). I do not have an enlarged prostate. All worsen at least temporarily and depending on the IPSS score may preclude this as an option. Guess I need to have a check up with my Uro to see where I'm at. Did I just answer my own question? The Radiologist Oncologist prescribed flowmax to help lessen the symptoms for now Any comments?

Posts.Title: psa

Posts.Content: Urinary symptoms first started around 2010, slower stream, nocturnia, occasional urgency. but was minor, just assumed part of the aging process. 2011, first PSA 5 with free PSA of 26%. Re-test after Cipro, 4.3. Waited a little over one year before another PSA which came in at 5.6. Biopsy results, 8 of 12 cores positive, G6's and 7's. 5%-40% cancer involvement in various cores, both lobes, including apex and base with perineural invasion noted on my second pathology read, from Oppenheimer labs. First path report had G7 as 4+3, second from nationally known lab had them at 3+4's Currently Prostate slightly enlarged at 39cc, latest PSA 5.9, but that's after various poking and prodding. I have opted for the trifecta, or triple play, short term hormone, 2 weeks of Casodex, followed by a 6 month course of Lupron. Three months into the hormone therapy, I start a 5 week course of IMRT, or external beam radiation, followed by permanent Brachy therapy (seed implant) Any comments on what to expect, and anyone have any personal experience with radiation oncologist Dr John Steel the Tampa Bay Florida area? Any foods or supplements that might be helpful during the upcoming festivities? Waiting till after holidays to pop the first pill Train about to leave the station....

AgeInfo.Phrase: Currently Prostate slightly enlarged at 39cc  latest PSA 5 9  but

Posts.Title: Diet or supplement recommendations to aid treatment plan? ebrt/seeds/adt

Posts.Content: Thanks, I'd be lost without this support. My RO, has done over 4,000 seed implants. There is also the Datoli center about 2-1/2 hours south of where I live. They have a very good rep and they have responded immediately to my e-mails. You send them your stats and they will do a free phone consult with one of their physicians. Haven't done that yet. They are out of network but my yearly maximum is capped at 5,000. after that it's paid.

Posts.Title: For EBRT, what's best? For Brachy Minimize Symptoms

Posts.Content: Hope I'm not asking too many questions, but it's coming up to crunch time for a decision to be made. What EBRT has the most accuracy with the least collateral damage. IMRT, 3DCRT, Proton beam, other? (proven technologies) For Brachy, any tips to minimize symptoms, retention, burning, nocturnia, urge? As for staging can someone help, my Uro told me T1C, RO said it's T2A, the Onc Uro said T2C PSA 5.6/ 8 cores with less than 50% for any core, both sides equally affected, clean DRE
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: For EBRT, what's best? For Brachy Minimize Symptoms

Posts.Content: From their website, any comments on how much of this is marketing hype? For more than 40 years the evolution of radiation delivery technologies has been based upon a single objective: maximize the dose to the tumor while minimizing the dose to surrounding normal tissue. Today the most advanced beam technology available is DART using all methods of 4D IG-IMRT and the Dattoli Cancer Center was the first facility in America to offer it to patients. More patients with prostate cancer have been treated with DART at Dattoli Cancer Center than any other center in the world by fourfold. Moreover, DCC boasts having the most sophisticated technologies to achieve DART, providing every patient with a cutting edge experience. DART may also referred to as "Smart Beam" technology because of its extraordinary ability to cast thousands of precisely targeted radiation "beamlets" or "microbeams,"on a 360-degree radius, not only into the prostate, plus a carefully delineated margin, but also in escalating doses directly into the tumor(-s) while de-escalating doses to the urethra. A unique treatment blueprint is mapped out in advance for each patient. With computer planning and three-dimensional imaging techniques, it is possible to more accurately deliver radiation to satisfy pre-defined dose specifications to the tumor while avoiding nearby healthy tissue. Thus, the risk of damaging the bowel, bladder, rectum and other organs is significantly reduced. At the same time, the cancer-killing dose of radiation is maximized on the designated target.
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: For EBRT, what's best? For Brachy Minimize Symptoms

Posts.Content: I am 3 weeks ahead of you guys. Now that I've had time to calm down and gather info, I am going with external beam radiation, 5 weeks, 15 minutes a day, five days a week, followed by Brachy therapy, or radioactive seed implants. Makes the most sense to me with my stats. I recommend that you consult with a radiologist oncologist who specializes in PC Because of your PSA level, temporary hormone therapy may be included for a 3 prong approach. This will shrink the prostate and start working against the cancer cells right away. This can be a very good option instead of surgery Check the following site to educate yourself for all options http://www.yananow.org/StrangePlace/forest.html
Posts.Title: husband 48 just diagnosed - info needed please

Posts.Content: Diagnosed 11/09, been getting tests, consults and stressing out. Same time as some unresolved dental work. Started Tamsulosin to help with flow problems in the meantime, resulting in poor sleep due to congestion, add it all together and.... If you've had chicken pox when you were younger, there is a dormant virus left behind that waits for a trigger to wreak havoc, this long term stress did me in, Started with burning painful skin, in various areas, like I had a serious sunburn, seemed to emanate from right hip, down right thigh, immediately thought bone mets, what else? The pain moved up and across the mid section and back, on day 4, a serious blotchy rash occurred, this when I am starting short term hormone therapy, this just sucks. Welcome to the world of shingles, herpes zoster(no not that kind) look it up. any advice would be appreciated. There is a vaccine to prevent this, and if you expect to be in a prolonged period of stress, please look into it
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Stress leads to additional problems. My Story as a warning

Posts.Content: Thanks Sarg, Dr Dattoli prescribed terazosin as a replacement for tamsulosin, said it's as effective without the congestion side-effects. Just started a few days ago, so far, no stuffy sinuses, but I guess it's too early to tell. It's also generic so look into it
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Stress leads to additional problems. My Story as a warning

Posts.Content: I was recently diagnosed 11/09. Treatment needs to be tailored to each particular case. For me, a combo of low dose EBRT, followed by seeds with short term hormone is my choice. A urological oncologist I consulted recommended surgery with radiation to follow. I decided not to face the possibility of side effects from both treatment forms. With surgery, they make the decision how much to remove during the surgery, they will check for positive margins and they widen the area to be removed, if warranted, while you're sleeping, making the decision how far to go, nerve bundles, lymph nodes, and they may still leave positive margins... I researched this non-stop since listening in disbelief to my own report..take your time and do not rush into anything. For either choice you want the best most experienced practitioner you can find. For me I am at peace with my decision at The Dattoli Center in Florida. Check out their website.. The other RO I was consulting with had done over 4,000 seed implants, experience is key even if you have to travel, if financially feasible Other good site for info YANA NOW Good luck,
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Help! Which Treatment - 1) Robotic Surgery, or 2) Hormones, Radiation & Seeds?

Posts.Content: Would be helpful to know PSA , free PSA, rise if any in the PSA over the years, any symptoms, etc..and what percentage of the cores were found with G6. With a low PSA and those numbers, the cancer may indolent and be a non factor in his eventual departure from this world, meaning he will most likely die of something else, not prostate cancer. If I had those numbers I personally would go into the active surveillance mode and not rush into anything. Educate yourself to all the options first. Any treatment has risks, some with permanent side effects that can diminish your quality of life forever. There is no rush for the case you presented. And these pro surgery stories are anecdotal anyway, there are no shortage of people who regret the decisions they've made. The treatment also depends on staging and tumor location, with a higher percentage of tumors in the apex with perineural invasion, other treatments make more sense, at least for me Good place to start, see what others chose and how they fared http://www.yananow.org/query_stories.php
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Young man with confusing options

Posts.Content: You didn't mention the Gleason Score, but I'm assuming it is a 6 or less? The PSA is not spot-on accurate, I believe there is a range that it can fluctuate between testing and for many reasons. What to look for is doubling time, symptoms and a suspicious DRE. Also did you have the free PSA checked? A free-PSA percentage of less than 15% is associated with a higher risk of prostate cancer. A free-PSA percentage of more than 25% is associated with a low risk of prostate cancer. Based on what you posted, you seem like a perfect AS candidate. I wish I had that report, I'd be waiting(my personal take on it only) With all the treatments, there can be significant problems. It's not simply removing a cancerous tumor and your done, as in a more isolated area.
Posts.Title: Hi -- any "active surveillors" out there?

Posts.Content: Great Info here, http://www.yananow.org/StrangePlace/forest.html
Posts.Title: Hi -- any "active surveillors" out there?

Posts.Content: Wow, what a wild ride it's been and it's starting First, the Uro told me my prostate was unusually small. After his biopsy, came back at 64cc. Next, pelvic MRI w/contrast simply stated, enlarged prostate indenting the bladder. Next up, an ultra sound ordered by my RO. Prostate at 40cc, however, only sightly enlarged, but at the median lobe, impinging the bladder neck, causing my urinary problems. I'm thinking a turp would be needed are beneficial prior to the treatment, to reduce the risk of problems during treatment. any advice? Or experience with turps? Please tell me you're not awake during it
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Turp Berfore IMRT/Seeds

Posts.Content: PSA3, The major difference between PCA3 (Prostate CAncer gene 3) and prostate specific antigen (PSA) is the fact that PCA3 is prostate cancer (PCa)-specific and PSA is not. PCA3 is, unlike PSA, only produced by PCa cells and not affected by prostate size. Therefore, the PCA3 Score better than PSA predicts the presence of PCa in a subsequent biopsy. Might get that prior to the next biopsy Color Doppler Ultrasound guided biopsy, I believe with that, if you have cancer it will most likely be located. I didn't have the PCA3, but my first biopsy was 8 of 12 positive. I have been on terazosin for 3 months, I assume it's in the same family. minor side effects have gone away, helps with flow and nocturnia caused from an enlarged prostate with growth in the median lobe, separate problem from PCa, needed an additional treatment for that, a green light laser trim, in the middle of HT, DART and prior to seeding, It's been a fun ride so far....................
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Apo Alfuzosin prescribed as head towards MRI to scan the prostate

Posts.Content: Thinking turp only due to the enlarged prostate, as luck would have it, bulging slightly at the bladder neck, the biopsy put me over the edge with urinary retention with an overwhelming urge to go at the same time, bad combo, and almost ended up getting a catheter at 4 am. dodged that bullet, but barely Just read possible turp side effects, seems worse than the treatment side effects. almost makes me want to forget the whole thing and simply deal with the symptoms as they come up, as in opting out of treament
Posts.Signature: 56 Yrs Old 2007 PSA 2.9 2011 PSA 5 2012 PSA 5.6 Nov 2012 1st Biopsy 12 core 8 of 12 Positive 5%-40% Apex/Base T2c Perineural Involvement
Posts.Title: Turp Berfore IMRT/Seeds

DoctorRecommended.Sample: Surgery would not, again primarily due to extent of apex and base involvement with perineural invasion I did also have a second read on the pathology report, it was similar except the core percentages changed slightly and the 7's in the second report went from 4=3 to 3=4 and added preineural invasion present. I would highly recommend getting a second report because your treatment flows from that, in my case it was similar enough not to change my outcome The urology oncologist is a surgeon who specializes in bladder reconstruction, so that's a plus for the urinary sphincter proximity to the apex tumor, he said he has done thousands of open prostatectomies and 400 robotic, and he now does only robotic Highlander, how did the surgeon know of the extent of positive margin prior to surgery?...For me, a combo of low dose EBRT, followed by seeds with short term hormone is my choice. A urological oncologist I consulted recommended surgery with radiation to follow....A urological oncologist I consulted recommended surgery with radiation to follow. I decided not to face the possibility of side effects from both treatment forms....
